poem:
"An Unexpected Bend in the Journey"

The morning bus took him to Croydon, how strange,
A routine turn shifting suddenly askew.
Man with Sudanese roots, now walking Rwanda's range.
The unexpected path is seldom jubilant, new.
In the palpable echo of detained hearts,
Spreads a whisper of questions, wringing the pendulum's sway.
One bill, one signature, where does our humanity start, where does it fray?
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Man detained by Home Office told he is being sent to Rwanda, says charity An asylum seeker who turned up for a routine Home Office appointment on Monday was detained and told that he was being sent to Rwanda, a charity has said. In what is believed to be the first potential deportation case since Rishi Sunak’s Rwanda bill received royal assent, the Sudanese man was held in Croydon, south London, the charity Soas Detainee". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
